elements.content: The coordination chemistry of a flexible N-donor ligand di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine (dpma) with silver salts has been investigated. Six new silver coordination polymers, namely, [Ag(dpma)(H2O)]­(NO3) (1), [Ag(dpma)(CF3CO2)]­·1/2H2O (2), [Ag(dpma)](CF3SO3)­·1/2H2O (3), [Ag(dpma)]­(BF4)­·3/2H2O (4), [Ag3(dpma)2(H2O)]­(ClO4)3 (5), and [Ag(dpma)](PF6) (6), have been prepared by slow diffusion reactions. All the polymeric structures of compounds 1–6 are described as topologic binodal networks in terms of Ag and dpma building blocks. Compounds 1–4 show a one-dimensional ladder-like chain structure, with both Ag and dpma as three-connected T-nodes; compound 5 is an uncommon one-dimensional metallamacrocycle-based chain structure, with Ag as two-connected I-node and dpma as three-connected T-node; compound 6 is a two-dimensional honeycomb-like layer structure, with both Ag and dpma as three-connected Y-nodes. Within the structures, the dpma ligand adopts a variety of structure conformations including gauche–trans–anti (1 and 2), trans–trans–anti (3 and 4), trans–trans–syn (3), gauche–gauche–syn (5), and trans–gauche–syn (6) conformations. For these Ag–dpma coordination polymers, the structural diversity and complexity are most likely attributed to the different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect of the counteranions and solvent molecules. Solution studies suggest that compounds 1–6 would disaggregate to break down the polymeric structures and then to give multiple rapidly exchanging solution species in DMSO or acetonitrile. The thermal stabilities of compounds 1–6 are examined. In addition, the photoluminescent properties of compounds 1–6 are investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Anions with different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect have a profound effect upon the conformational variation of the flexible di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine ligand, leading to the structural modulation of Ag(I) coordination polymers including one-dimensional ladder-like and metallamacrocycle-based chains and two-dimensional honeycomb-like layer.

elements.content: Over the past decades, there has been a deal of great interest in constructing the variety of coordination polymers due to the realization of their intriguing structural diversity and potential for use as functional materials. The vast majority of these materials are formed by the combination of metal ions/clusters and organic bridging ligands via metal–ligand coordination bonds. In such a course, studies of the control of framework structure and topology are based on the judicious selection of the constituent building blocks, i.e., the metal ions and network-forming ligands, and crystallization conditions. For a given system, the factors that affect the final structures and functions of coordination polymers include the nature of the counteranions, the molar ratio of the reagents, and the composition of the solvent media, among others. Therefore, understanding of influencing factors in self-assembly based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks is helpful to get access to the generation of desirable products showing unique structure and function.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, there has been a deal of great interest in constructing the variety of coordination polymers due to the realization of their intriguing structural diversity and potential for use as functional materials. The vast majority of these materials are formed by the combination of metal ions/clusters and organic bridging ligands via metal-ligand coordination bonds. In such a course, studies of the control of framework structure and topology are based on the judicious selection of the constituent building blocks, i.e., the metal ions and network-forming ligands, and crystallization conditions. For a given system, the factors that affect the final structures and functions of coordination polymers include the nature of the counteranions, the molar ratio of the reagents, and the composition of the solvent media, among others. Therefore, understanding of influencing factors in self-assembly based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks is helpful to get access to the generation of desirable products showing unique structure and function.

elements.content: The N-donor ligands, such as 4,4′-bipyridine and its various derivatives, are excellent neutral ligands to form rich architectures exhibiting fascinating polymeric structural motifs and remarkable physical properties with various metal ions. Many efforts have so far been devoted to designing such ingenious bipyridine-type ligands having an innocent (incapable of forming hydrogen bonds) or a noninnocent (capable of forming hydrogen bonds) backbone. Recently, we have applied a bipyridine-type ligand di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine (dpma), which has two 3-pyridyl ligating groups that are connected by a certain three-atomic (−CH2NHCH2−) backbone equipped with an amine group, in the construction of discrete and polymeric Cu(II)-based coordination architectures. With the conformational flexibility, the dpma ligand can present various structure conformations (trans–trans, trans–gauche, and gauche–gauche) and different donating orientations (syn and anti), which understandably induce diverse ligating topologies (linear and angular). In addition, the amine group present on the ligand allows for hydrogen bonding in the resultant coordination architectures.

Many efforts have so far been devoted to designing such ingenious bipyridine-type ligands having an innocent (incapable of forming hydrogen bonds) or a noninnocent (capable of forming hydrogen bonds) backbone. Recently, we have applied a bipyridine-type ligand di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine (dpma), which has two 3-pyridyl ligating groups that are connected by a certain three-atomic (-CH2NHCH2-) backbone equipped with an amine group, in the construction of discrete and polymeric Cu(II)-based coordination architectures. With the conformational flexibility, the dpma ligand can present various structure conformations (trans-trans, trans-gauche, and gauche-gauche) and different donating orientations (syn and anti), which understandably induce diverse ligating topologies (linear and angular). In addition, the amine group present on the ligand allows for hydrogen bonding in the resultant coordination architectures.

elements.content: The soft acid Ag(I) ion has a dynamic range of coordinative variations from two to six, even seven and eight, and shows a strong tendency to display versatile coordination spheres. This variety is in part due to the lack of stereochemical preference that arises from the d10 electronic configuration and the relatively weak nature of the silver···ligand bond. Thus, the Ag(I) ion can serve as an excellent candidate to link bridging ligands and form polymeric networks with novel coordination patterns. In such coordination architectures, the role of anions is particularly noticeable. Usually, anions chosen for their “relative innocence” in terms of coordinating ability can nevertheless direct the course of an assembly process via noncovalent interactions. In fact, as representative examples, anions being a permanent part of the final product can influence the structure either by coordinating directly to the metal centers or by acting as templates that preorganize the organic building blocks used to build up the assembly. Therefore, the ancillary ligation by different counteranions, such as NO3 – , PF6 – , SbF6 – , ClO4 – , BF4 – , CF3SO3 – , CF3CO2 – , CH3CO2 – , and so on, or solvent molecules may cause a significant structural change of the resultant polymers.

elements.content: In this paper, we report a family of new coordination polymers resulting from the coordination reaction of the flexible divergent dpma ligand and Ag(I) ion with different counteranions. The aim of the investigations is to study the coordination chemistry of dpma ligand with soft Ag(I) ion and to explore the templating effect of counteranions, the ligating topology about the ligand conformation, and the role of orientation of coordination sites in the self-assembly process. These silver–dpma coordination polymers exhibit luminescence behavior in the solid state at room temperature.

These silver-dpma coordination polymers exhibit luminescence behavior in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Chemical reagents were purchased commercially and were used as received without further purification. Di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine (dpma) ligand was prepared according to literature methods. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX-300 Solution-NMR spectrometer. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvent. Coupling constants are given in Hertz. Electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were measured on a Waters LCT Premier XE (Waters Corp., Manchester, UK) with dual ionization ESCi (ESI/APCi) source options. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under nitrogen with a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TG analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were recorded on a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer at 40 kV, 30 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a step size of 0.02° in θ and a scan speed of 1 s per step size. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer RX1 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr discs in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a CARy 50 Probe spectrophotometer. Solution-state fluorescence spectra were obtained in acetonitrile solution at ambient temperature with a JASCO FP-6300 spectrofluorometer. Solid-state fluorescence and excitation spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III analytical instrument.

Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

Chemical reagents were purchased commercially and were used as received without further purification. Di(3-pyridylmethyl)amine (dpma) ligand was prepared according to literature methods. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX-300 Solution-NMR spectrometer. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvent. Coupling constants are given in Hertz. Electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were measured on a Waters LCT Premier XE (Waters Corp., Manchester, UK) with dual ionization ESCi (ESI/APCi) source options. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under nitrogen with a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TG analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were recorded on a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer at 40 kV, 30 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a step size of 0.02° in θ and a scan speed of 1 s per step size. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer RX1 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr discs in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a CARy 50 Probe spectrophotometer. Solution-state fluorescence spectra were obtained in acetonitrile solution at ambient temperature with a JASCO FP-6300 spectrofluorometer. Solid-state fluorescence and excitation spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III analytical instrument.

elements.content: A solution of dpma (39.8 mg, 0.20 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was carefully layered on top of a mixture of MeOH and H2O (6 mL, 1:1 v/v, middle) and a solution of AgNO3 (33.9 mg, 0.20 mmol) in H2O (5 mL, bottom) at room temperature. The solution was allowed to stand for approximately two weeks, resulting in the formation of colorless granule-shaped crystals. Yield 29% (22.1 mg, 0.057 mmol). Alternatively, 1 was also prepared using a procedure similar to that mentioned above except that THF was used in the solvent system instead of MeOH. Yield 42%. Anal. Calcd for C12H15AgN4O4: C, 37.23; H, 3.91; N, 14.47%. Found: C, 37.59; H, 4.12; N, 14.90%. IR (KBr pellet): 3753, 3040, 2851, 2692, 1761, 1596, 1578, 1478, 1458, 1429, 1232, 1189, 1046, 1030, 985, 932, 870, 824, 796, 706, 646 cm–1.

elements.content: Data collections for 1 and 5 were performed on a Bruker Smart CCD-based diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collections for 2 and 4 were performed on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer configured with a PHOTO100 CMOS detector. Data for 3 were collected by using an Oxford Diffraction Gemini S diffractometer. Data for 6 were collected by using a KappaCCD diffractometer. Starting models for structure refinement were found using direct methods (SHELXS-97 for 1–5 and SHELXS-86 for 6), and the structural data were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the WINGX and SHELX-97 program packages. All non-hydrogen atoms were found from the different Fourier maps and refined anisotropically, with the exception of O11 and O11′ in 3, and B1, B2, F1–F8, and O1–O3 in 4. Generally, carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed by geometrical calculation and refined as riding mode. Nitrogen- and oxygen-bound hydrogen atoms were first located on difference Fourier maps and then fixed at calculated positions and included in the final refinement. Isotropic displacement parameters of all hydrogen atoms were derived from the parent atoms. For 2, one of the trifluoroacetate oxygen atoms was split over two sites (O1A and O1B) with equal occupancies. For 3, one trifluoromethanesulfonate anion was split over two sites with refined occupancies of 0.55 and 0.45 and was treated with refinement of disorder using the PART instructions. The trifluoromethanesulfonate oxygens O11 and O11′ in the major and minor entities, respectively, were refined with isotropic thermal parameters. For 4, both the B(1)F4 – and B(2)F4 – anions were disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation and, therefore, were treated as half-occupied entities. Refinement of the disorder in BF4 – anions was performed with the SADI, SIMU, and DELU routines. Additionally, a total of 1.5 lattice water molecules (O1–O3) in the asymmetric unit were found to be disordered over three general positions with the same occupancy of 0.5, which led to the short contacts between water molecules. No attempt was made to locate the hydrogen atoms of the disordered lattice water molecules. The boron, fluorine, and oxygen atoms were refined with isotropic thermal parameters. For 5, the Cl(1)O4 – anion lay on a 2-fold axis of rotation with one fully occupied oxygen atom (O1) and one disordered oxygen atom that was split over two equal-occupied sites (O2A and O2B). The Cl(2)O4 anion lay on a general position and its disordered oxygen atoms O3A–O6A and O3B–O6B as having a 50:50 site-occupancy were treated with refinement of disorder using the PART instructions. The coordinated O(11) water molecule was disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation and, therefore, was modeled as a half-occupied entity. Experimental details for X-ray data collection and the refinements are summarized in Table .

For 3, one trifluoromethanesulfonate anion was split over two sites with refined occupancies of 0.55 and 0.45 and was treated with refinement of disorder using the PART instructions. The trifluoromethanesulfonate oxygens O11 and O11' in the major and minor entities, respectively, were refined with isotropic thermal parameters. For 4, both the B(1)F4 - and B(2)F4 - anions were disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation and, therefore, were treated as half-occupied entities. Refinement of the disorder in BF4 - anions was performed with the SADI, SIMU, and DELU routines. Additionally, a total of 1.5 lattice water molecules (O1-O3) in the asymmetric unit were found to be disordered over three general positions with the same occupancy of 0.5, which led to the short contacts between water molecules. No attempt was made to locate the hydrogen atoms of the disordered lattice water molecules. The boron, fluorine, and oxygen atoms were refined with isotropic thermal parameters. For 5, the Cl(1)O4 - anion lay on a 2-fold axis of rotation with one fully occupied oxygen atom (O1) and one disordered oxygen atom that was split over two equal-occupied sites (O2A and O2B). The Cl(2)O4 anion lay on a general position and its disordered oxygen atoms O3A-O6A and O3B-O6B as having a 50:50 site-occupancy were treated with refinement of disorder using the PART instructions. The coordinated O(11) water molecule was disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation and, therefore, was modeled as a half-occupied entity. Experimental details for X-ray data collection and the refinements are summarized in Table .

The slow diffusion reactions of an organic (MeOH or THF) solution of dpma into an aqueous solution of AgX (X– = NO3 –, CF3CO2 –, CF3SO3 –, ClO4 –, PF6 –) or a THF solution of AgBF4 afforded the 1:1 Ag(I)–dpma adducts for NO3 –, CF3CO2 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and PF6 – and a 3:2 adduct for ClO4 – (Scheme ). All these reactions were not affected by the metal-to-ligand ratio. Their molecular structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray structure analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, infrared (IR) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns confirmed the phase purity of the bulk materials (Figure S1–S6, ).

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The slow diffusion reactions of an organic (MeOH or THF) solution of dpma into an aqueous solution of AgX (X- = NO3 -, CF3CO2 -, CF3SO3 -, ClO4 -, PF6 -) or a THF solution of AgBF4 afforded the 1:1 Ag(I)-dpma adducts for NO3 -, CF3CO2 -, CF3SO3 -, BF4 -, and PF6 - and a 3:2 adduct for ClO4 - (Scheme ). All these reactions were not affected by the metal-to-ligand ratio. Their molecular structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray structure analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, infrared (IR) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns confirmed the phase purity of the bulk materials (Figure S1-S6, ).

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with the asymmetric unit containing one silver atom, one dpma ligand, one aqua ligand, and one nitrate anion. The Ag atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens (Npy) of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy = 2.299(2) and 2.314(2) Å (Table S1, ), one amine nitrogen (Nam) of third dpma ligand, with Ag–Nam = 2.289(2) Å, and one aqua oxygen, with Ag–O = 2.558(2) Å, forming a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry (N–Ag–N = 104.20(8)–127.18(8)°, N–Ag–O = 86.09(8)–102.56(8)°, and Ag···N3-basal plane =0.21 Å), as shown in . In turn, the dpma ligand coordinates to three Ag atoms in a gauche–trans–anti conformation.

Structural Analysis of [Ag(dpma)(H2O)](NO3) (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with the asymmetric unit containing one silver atom, one dpma ligand, one aqua ligand, and one nitrate anion. The Ag atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens (Npy) of two different dpma ligands, with Ag-Npy = 2.299(2) and 2.314(2) Å (Table S1, ), one amine nitrogen (Nam) of third dpma ligand, with Ag-Nam = 2.289(2) Å, and one aqua oxygen, with Ag-O = 2.558(2) Å, forming a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry (N-Ag-N = 104.20(8)-127.18(8)°, N-Ag-O = 86.09(8)-102.56(8)°, and Ag⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane =0.21 Å), as shown in . In turn, the dpma ligand coordinates to three Ag atoms in a gauche-trans-anti conformation.

elements.content: Compound 1 forms a one-dimensional chain structure (Figures a and ), where the amine hydrogens of the dpma ligands all point to the same direction, i.e., an up-up-up-up (uuuu) manner, with respect to the Ag–dpma chain. The nitrate counteranions are not involved in the Ag coordination sphere but are hydrogen bonded to amine hydrogens of the dpma ligands through N–H···O interactions (N···O = 3.013(3) Å, Table ) and to the aqua ligands through O–H···O interactions (O···O = 2.813(3)–3.306(3) Å), as shown in Figure a. With the nitrate···aqua hydrogen bonds, a supramolecular hydrogen-bonded nitrate–aqua (NO3–H2O) helical chain with a pitch of 11.64 Å running along the crystallographic c axis is therefore formed (Figure b). However, there are no significant interactions between two adjacent chains (). Therefore, the nitrate counteranions probably act as templates for the formation of the resultant supramolecular network.

With the nitrate⋅⋅⋅aqua hydrogen bonds, a supramolecular hydrogen-bonded nitrate-aqua (NO3-H2O) helical chain with a pitch of 11.64 Å running along the crystallographic c axis is therefore formed (Figure b). Therefore, the nitrate counteranions probably act as templates for the formation of the resultant supramolecular network.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with the asymmetric unit containing two silver atoms, two distinct dpma ligands, and two trifluoroacetate anions as well as a lattice water molecule. The Ag(1) atom, as shown in , is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy = 2.326(2) and 2.353(2) Å (), one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag–Nam = 2.277(2) Å, and one trifluoroacetate oxygen, which is split over two sites with occupancies of 0.50 and 0.50, with Ag–O = 2.455(12)–2.480(12) Å. The Ag(2) atom is surrounded by a set of N3O donors consisting of two pyridine nitrogens and one amine nitrogen of three different dpma ligands and one trifluoroacetate oxygen, with Ag–Npy = 2.331(2) and 2.352(2) Å, Ag–Nam = 2.297(2) Å, and Ag–O = 2.439(2) Å. As a result, the two crystallographically distinct silver atoms, Ag(1) and Ag(2), both adopt a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry, where the N–Ag–N and N–Ag–O angles and the Ag···N3-basal plane distance are 97.90(8)–129.11(7)°, 88.1(3)–110.7(2)°, and 0.38 Å, respectively, for the Ag(1) atom, and 98.76(8)–127.99(7)°, 92.60(7)–105.69(7)°, and 0.43 Å, respectively, for the Ag(2) atom. The two crystallographically distinct dpma ligands both adopt a gauche–trans–anti conformation and coordinate to three Ag atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis of [Ag(dpma)(CF3CO2)]⋅1/2H2O (2)

Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with the asymmetric unit containing two silver atoms, two distinct dpma ligands, and two trifluoroacetate anions as well as a lattice water molecule. The Ag(1) atom, as shown in , is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag-Npy = 2.326(2) and 2.353(2) Å (), one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag-Nam = 2.277(2) Å, and one trifluoroacetate oxygen, which is split over two sites with occupancies of 0.50 and 0.50, with Ag-O = 2.455(12)-2.480(12) Å. The Ag(2) atom is surrounded by a set of N3O donors consisting of two pyridine nitrogens and one amine nitrogen of three different dpma ligands and one trifluoroacetate oxygen, with Ag-Npy = 2.331(2) and 2.352(2) Å, Ag-Nam = 2.297(2) Å, and Ag-O = 2.439(2) Å. As a result, the two crystallographically distinct silver atoms, Ag(1) and Ag(2), both adopt a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry, where the N-Ag-N and N-Ag-O angles and the Ag⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane distance are 97.90(8)-129.11(7)°, 88.1(3)-110.7(2)°, and 0.38 Å, respectively, for the Ag(1) atom, and 98.76(8)-127.99(7)°, 92.60(7)-105.69(7)°, and 0.43 Å, respectively, for the Ag(2) atom. The two crystallographically distinct dpma ligands both adopt a gauche-trans-anti conformation and coordinate to three Ag atoms.

elements.content: Compound 2 has an infinite one-dimensional chain structure (Figures b and ). Compared to the uuuu manner in 1, the amine hydrogens within the Ag–dpma chain structure of 2 shows an up-down-up-down (udud) arrangement in orientation. It is worth noting that these Ag–dpma coordination-chains align in an AAA sequence along the crystallographic a axis and there are chain-to-chain N–H···O hydrogen bonds (N···O = 3.088(3) Å, Table ) between the amine hydrogens in one chain and the trifluoroacetate anions in neighboring chain. These interchain hydrogen bonds stitch these one-dimensional chains into a supramolecular two-dimensional hydrogen-bonded layer structure (Figure ). The lattice H2O molecules act as hydrogen-bond-acceptors for the Ag–dpma coordination-chains through N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (N···O = 2.895(3) Å) and as hydrogen-bond-donors for the trifluoroacetate anions of neighboring chains through O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (O···O = 2.796(3)–2.800(3) Å); this undoubtedly provides further support for stabilizing the extensive supramolecular layer structure. As a result, the trifluoroacetate anion has a profound effect upon the resultant network.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with the asymmetric unit containing four silver atoms, four distinct dpma ligands, and four trifluoromethanesulfonate anions as well as two lattice water molecules. The four crystallographically distinct Ag atoms, Ag(1), Ag(2), Ag(3), and Ag(4), show comparable coordination environments (). The Ag(1) atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy =2.264(3) and 2.320(3) Å (), one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag–Nam =2.284(2) Å, and one trifluoromethanesulfonate anion, with Ag–O = 2.523(3) Å, forming a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry (N–Ag(1)–N = 100.30(10)–134.26(9)° and N–Ag(1)–O = 88.45(11)–107.20(11)°, and Ag(1)···N3-basal plane = 0.31 Å). The coordination spheres around the other three Ag atoms all consist of two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands (Ag(2)–Npy = 2.267(3) and 2.346(3) Å; Ag(3)–Npy = 2.292(3) and 2.296(3) Å; Ag(4)–Npy = 2.243(4) and 2.311(3) Å) and one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand (Ag(2)–Nam =2.279(3); Ag(3)–Nam = 2.290(3) Å; Ag(4)–Nam = 2.213(3) Å) to form three-coordinate distorted trigonal planar geometries (N–Ag(2)–N = 100.09(10)–137.79(10)°; N–Ag(3)–N = 109.16(9)–121.37(10)°; N–Ag(4)–N = 98.67(12)–136.85(11)°). However, two further trifluoromethanesulfonate anions are weakly involved in the coordination spheres of Ag(2) and Ag(3) atoms through weak Ag···O interactions (Ag(2)···O3S(3)CF3 = 2.68 Å and Ag(3)···O3S(2)CF3 = 2.69 Å). Although these Ag···O distances are relatively long, they are all significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for Ag and O (3.24 Å). Therefore, the coordination spheres for Ag(2) and Ag(3) can be regarded as 3 + 1 capped trigonal planar geometries, where Ag(2)···N3-basal plane = 0.14 Å and Ag(3)···N3-basal plane = 0.39 Å. The four crystallographic distinct dpma ligands all coordinate to three Ag atoms. Three of them adopt a trans–trans–anti conformation, while the last one suits a trans–trans–syn conformation.

Structural Analysis of [Ag(dpma)](CF3SO3)⋅1/2H2O (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with the asymmetric unit containing four silver atoms, four distinct dpma ligands, and four trifluoromethanesulfonate anions as well as two lattice water molecules. The four crystallographically distinct Ag atoms, Ag(1), Ag(2), Ag(3), and Ag(4), show comparable coordination environments (). The Ag(1) atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag-Npy =2.264(3) and 2.320(3) Å (), one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag-Nam =2.284(2) Å, and one trifluoromethanesulfonate anion, with Ag-O = 2.523(3) Å, forming a four-coordinate capped trigonal planar geometry (N-Ag(1)-N = 100.30(10)-134.26(9)° and N-Ag(1)-O = 88.45(11)-107.20(11)°, and Ag(1)⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane = 0.31 Å). The coordination spheres around the other three Ag atoms all consist of two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands (Ag(2)-Npy = 2.267(3) and 2.346(3) Å; Ag(3)-Npy = 2.292(3) and 2.296(3) Å; Ag(4)-Npy = 2.243(4) and 2.311(3) Å) and one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand (Ag(2)-Nam =2.279(3); Ag(3)-Nam = 2.290(3) Å; Ag(4)-Nam = 2.213(3) Å) to form three-coordinate distorted trigonal planar geometries (N-Ag(2)-N = 100.09(10)-137.79(10)°; N-Ag(3)-N = 109.16(9)-121.37(10)°; N-Ag(4)-N = 98.67(12)-136.85(11)°). However, two further trifluoromethanesulfonate anions are weakly involved in the coordination spheres of Ag(2) and Ag(3) atoms through weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O interactions (Ag(2)⋅⋅⋅O3S(3)CF3 = 2.68 Å and Ag(3)⋅⋅⋅O3S(2)CF3 = 2.69 Å). Although these Ag⋅⋅⋅O distances are relatively long, they are all significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for Ag and O (3.24 Å). Therefore, the coordination spheres for Ag(2) and Ag(3) can be regarded as 3 + 1 capped trigonal planar geometries, where Ag(2)⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane = 0.14 Å and Ag(3)⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane = 0.39 Å. The four crystallographic distinct dpma ligands all coordinate to three Ag atoms. Three of them adopt a trans-trans-anti conformation, while the last one suits a trans-trans-syn conformation.

elements.content: Compound 3 has a one-dimensional chain structure (Figures c and ). Within the chain structure, the amine hydrogens stay in the way of an up-up-down-down (uudd) manner, which is different from those in 1 and 2. The four crystallographically distinct trifluoromethanesulfonate anions provide comparable efforts on coordination and hydrogen bonds to build the overall network of 3. The CF3S(1)O3 – anions show, in addition to the coordination to Ag(1) atoms, two sets of hydrogen-bonding interactions with the lattice H2O(21) molecules (O···O = 2.920(4)–2.904(5) Å, Table ); the CF3S(2)O3 – anions present one set of hydrogen-bonding interactions with the lattice H2O(22) molecules (O···O = 2.855(5) Å), in addition to the weak coordination to Ag(3) atoms; the CF3S(3)O3 – anions weakly bond to Ag(2) atoms and form two sets of hydrogen bonds (N···O = 3.070(4)–3.139(4) Å) with the amine groups of the dpma ligands in the same chain, and the disordered CF3S(4)O3 – anions locate near Ag(2) atoms with somewhat long Ag···O separations (Ag···O > 3.24 Å) and form hydrogen bonds with the lattice H2O(22) molecules (O···O = 2.80(3) Å). The two crystallographically distinct lattice H2O molecules, as shown in Figure a, both being as hydrogen-acceptor interact with the Ag–dpma coordination chains through N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (N···O = 2.890(5)–3.060(5) Å), in addition to being capable of hydrogen-donor toward trifluoromethanesulfonate anions (O···O = 2.80(3)–2.920(4) Å). These hydrogen bonding interactions associated with weak A···O contacts stitch these one-dimensional chains into a supramolecular three-dimensional hydrogen-bonded network (Figure b).

Within the chain structure, the amine hydrogens stay in the way of an up-up-down-down (uudd) manner, which is different from those in 1 and 2. The four crystallographically distinct trifluoromethanesulfonate anions provide comparable efforts on coordination and hydrogen bonds to build the overall network of 3. The CF3S(1)O3 - anions show, in addition to the coordination to Ag(1) atoms, two sets of hydrogen-bonding interactions with the lattice H2O(21) molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.920(4)-2.904(5) Å, Table ); the CF3S(2)O3 - anions present one set of hydrogen-bonding interactions with the lattice H2O(22) molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.855(5) Å), in addition to the weak coordination to Ag(3) atoms; the CF3S(3)O3 - anions weakly bond to Ag(2) atoms and form two sets of hydrogen bonds (N⋅⋅⋅O = 3.070(4)-3.139(4) Å) with the amine groups of the dpma ligands in the same chain, and the disordered CF3S(4)O3 - anions locate near Ag(2) atoms with somewhat long Ag⋅⋅⋅O separations (Ag⋅⋅⋅O > 3.24 Å) and form hydrogen bonds with the lattice H2O(22) molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.80(3) Å). The two crystallographically distinct lattice H2O molecules, as shown in Figure a, both being as hydrogen-acceptor interact with the Ag-dpma coordination chains through N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions (N⋅⋅⋅O = 2.890(5)-3.060(5) Å), in addition to being capable of hydrogen-donor toward trifluoromethanesulfonate anions (O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.80(3)-2.920(4) Å). These hydrogen bonding interactions associated with weak A⋅⋅⋅O contacts stitch these one-dimensional chains into a supramolecular three-dimensional hydrogen-bonded network (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pcca with the asymmetric unit containing one silver atom, one dpma ligand, and two half-occupied halves of tetrafluoroborate anions as well as a total of 1.5 lattice water molecules. The Ag atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy = 2.284(6) and 2.331(5) Å (), and one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag–Nam = 2.251(6) Å, arranging in a distorted trigonal planar geometry (N–Ag–N = 100.0(2)–135.7(2)°). Considering the longer Ag···F4B(1) distance of 2.87 Å, which is significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for Ag and F (3.19 Å), the Ag coordination geometry can be regarded as a 3 + 1 capped trigonal planar geometry with the Ag···N3-basal plane distance of 0.24 Å (). In turn, the dpma ligand adopting a trans–trans–syn conformation coordinates to three Ag atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis of [Ag(dpma)](BF4)⋅3/2H2O (4)

Compound 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pcca with the asymmetric unit containing one silver atom, one dpma ligand, and two half-occupied halves of tetrafluoroborate anions as well as a total of 1.5 lattice water molecules. The Ag atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag-Npy = 2.284(6) and 2.331(5) Å (), and one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag-Nam = 2.251(6) Å, arranging in a distorted trigonal planar geometry (N-Ag-N = 100.0(2)-135.7(2)°). Considering the longer Ag⋅⋅⋅F4B(1) distance of 2.87 Å, which is significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for Ag and F (3.19 Å), the Ag coordination geometry can be regarded as a 3 + 1 capped trigonal planar geometry with the Ag⋅⋅⋅N3-basal plane distance of 0.24 Å (). In turn, the dpma ligand adopting a trans-trans-syn conformation coordinates to three Ag atoms.

elements.content: Compound 4 forms an infinite one-dimensional zigzag chain structure (Figures d and ). The amine hydrogens within the chain structure direct at an up-up-down-down (uudd) arrangement; this is similar to that in 3 and is comparable with those in 1 and 2. The two crystallographically distinct tetrafluoroborate anions are both highly disordered and provide comparable efforts to the overall network of 4. The B(1)F4 – anions, which are disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation, weakly bridge to two symmetrically related Ag atoms of two neighboring Ag–dpma chains (Ag···F4B(1) = 2.87–3.19 Å), leading to an extended two-dimensional coordination layer on the ac plane (Figure a). In contrast, the B(2)F4 – anions are not involved in the Ag coordination sphere but form pertinent hydrogen bonds to the amine hydrogens (N···F = 2.928(15)–3.004(11) Å, Table ), demonstrating the formation of a supramolecular two-dimensional hydrogen-bonded layer on the ab plane (Figure b). The weak Ag···F contacts assisted coordination layers and the hydrogen-bonded supramolecular layers intercross each other via Ag atoms to be a supramolecular three-dimensional net (Figure b). Therefore, the tetrafluoroborate (BF4 –) anion has a profound effect upon the resultant network geometry. Besides, as shown in , the lattice H2O molecules also weakly contact the Ag atoms with Ag···O distances of 2.77 Å and form pertinent hydrogen bonds to the tetrafluoroborate (BF4 –) anions (O···F = 2.40–2.78 Å).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with the asymmetric unit containing one and half silver atoms, one dpma ligand, half of an aqua ligand, and one and a half perchlorate anions. The two crystallographically distinct silver atoms, Ag(1) and Ag(2), show comparable coordination environments (). Ag(1) atom lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by two amine nitrogens of two symmetry-related dpma ligands, with Ag–Nam = 2.192(6) Å (), and one aqua ligand, which is disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation, with Ag–O = 2.57(2) Å, arranging in a slightly deformed T-shaped geometry (N–Ag–N = 174.1(3)° and N–Ag–O = 85.4(9) and 100.5(9)°). Ag(2) atom lies at a general position and is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy = 2.166(6) and 2.166(7) Å, in an approximately linear fashion (N–Ag–N = 167.1(3)°). In addition, the Ag(2) atom is also weakly bonded to two disordered perchlorate anions, with Ag(2)···O4Cl(1) = 2.85 Å and Ag(2)···O4Cl(2) = 2.80–3.16 Å. Therefore, the Ag(2) atom has a 2 + 2 seesaw coordination geometry. In turn, the dpma ligand adopting a gauche–gauche–syn conformation coordinates to three Ag atoms.

The two crystallographically distinct silver atoms, Ag(1) and Ag(2), show comparable coordination environments (). Ag(1) atom lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by two amine nitrogens of two symmetry-related dpma ligands, with Ag-Nam = 2.192(6) Å (), and one aqua ligand, which is disordered over a 2-fold axis of rotation, with Ag-O = 2.57(2) Å, arranging in a slightly deformed T-shaped geometry (N-Ag-N = 174.1(3)° and N-Ag-O = 85.4(9) and 100.5(9)°). Ag(2) atom lies at a general position and is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag-Npy = 2.166(6) and 2.166(7) Å, in an approximately linear fashion (N-Ag-N = 167.1(3)°). In addition, the Ag(2) atom is also weakly bonded to two disordered perchlorate anions, with Ag(2)⋅⋅⋅O4Cl(1) = 2.85 Å and Ag(2)⋅⋅⋅O4Cl(2) = 2.80-3.16 Å. elements.content: Two Ag(2) atoms and two dpma ligands form a M2L2 metallamacrocycle with a Ag···Ag distance of 6.72 Å. These metallamacrocycles connect to each other by Ag(1) atoms via Ag–Nam bonds to generate an infinite one-dimensional metallamacrocycle-based chain structure (Figures a and ). The two crystallographically distinct perchlorate anions are highly disordered. The Cl(1)O4 – anions, which are situated on a 2-fold axis of rotation, weakly bridge to two symmetrically related Ag(2) atoms of two neighboring M2L2 metallacycles of the same Ag–dpma chain (). Comparably, the Cl(2)O4 – anion is not only a very weak terminal coligand around the Ag(2) atoms but also make contacts with the amine hydrogens through N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (N···O = 3.15(4)–3.287(17) Å, Table ) and to the aqua ligands through O–H···O interactions (O···O = 2.45–2.95 Å). Therefore, the perchlorate anion provides significant contributions for the fabrication of the resultant supramolecular three-dimensional H-bonded network. Along the crystallographic [101̅] direction, open channels accommodating Cl(2)O4 – perchlorate anions are formed with the stacking of these chains (Figure b).

The Ag atom, as shown in , is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogens of two different dpma ligands, with Ag–Npy = 2.238(4) and 2.364(5) Å (), and one amine nitrogen of one further dpma ligand, with Ag–Nam = 2.223(4) Å, forming a three-coordinate distorted trigonal planar geometry (N–Ag–N = 97.96(17)–140.67(16)°). elements.content: Compound 6 exists as an extended two-dimensional binodal honeycomb-like layer structure with both the Ag atom and dpma ligand as three-connected Y-nodes (Figure a). The amine hydrogens around the meshes of the honeycomb-layer are in either an up-up-down (uud) or an up-down-down (udd) arrangement with respect to the Ag–dpma layer. These layers stack in an ABAB sequence along the crystallographic c axis to give infinite layered openings lying on the ab plane, where hexafluorophosphate anions reside (Figures b and ). The hexafluorophosphate counteranions are not involved in the Ag coordination sphere but form pertinent hydrogen bonds to the amine hydrogens through N–H···F interactions (N···F = 3.016(6) Å, Table ). Accordingly, the hexafluorophosphate counteranions play an important role as anion templates in the construction of resultant network.

elements.content: In the present work, six novel low-dimensional Ag–dpma coordination polymers have been prepared by self-assembly from the ligand dpma and various silver salts of different counteranions NO3 –, CF3CO2 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, ClO4 –, and PF6 –. In the topological point of view, compounds 1–6 all are described as binodal infinite networks in terms of Ag and dpma building blocks. As shown in Figure , compounds 1–4 adopt a one-dimensional ladder-like chain structure where Ag and dpma are both considered as three-connected T-nodes; compound 5 has an unusual one-dimensional metallamacrocycle-based chain structure with Ag as two-connected I-node and dpma as three-connected T-node; and compound 6 is a two-dimensional honeycomb-like layer structure with both Ag and dpma as three-connected Y-nodes. The structural diversity and complexity in these Ag–dpma coordination polymers are presumably due to the different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect of the counteranions and solvent molecules. Though NO3 – usually functions as a moderately coordinating monodentate and bidentate anion, here it is not coordinated to the Ag(I) center in compound 1, and is acting as a template toward the formation of a topological ladder Ag–dpma coordination chain. Lacking coordination of the NO3 – anion to the Ag(I) leaves more room around the metal center, allowing the aqua ligand to coordinate to the Ag(I) ion. When a more strongly coordinating CF3CO2 – anion is used, the anions coordinate to Ag(I) ions through one of the oxygen atoms and serve as terminal ligands in compound 2. Changing to the other counteranions such as CF3SO3 – and BF4 – in compounds 3 and 4, respectively, has resulted in the formation of similar one-dimensional ladder structures, in which the CF3SO3 – and BF4 – are significantly involved in the coordination sphere of the Ag(I) center with weak Ag(I)···anion contacts. Incorporating weakly coordinating ClO4 – has afforded a completely different metallamacrocycle-based chain structure in 5. Significant Ag(I)···O4Cl and Ag(I)···OH2 weak coordination interactions are observed, leading to the seesaw and T-shaped Ag(I) coordination geometries. In the two-dimensional honeycomb-layer structure of 6, the noncoordinating PF6 – anions not only act as the counteranions to balance the charge but have a spatial templating effect in building up the coordination network. Moreover, these anions in compounds 1–6 all display noticeable hydrogen-bonding interactions with the amine hydrogens of the dpma ligands and coordinated/lattice water molecules probably act as templates for the formation of the network and consequently maintain the structural stability. However, a straightforward relationship between a given anion and the selective formation of a certain type of supramolecular structures is not yet well understood.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

In the present work, six novel low-dimensional Ag-dpma coordination polymers have been prepared by self-assembly from the ligand dpma and various silver salts of different counteranions NO3 -, CF3CO2 -, CF3SO3 -, BF4 -, ClO4 -, and PF6 -. In the topological point of view, compounds 1-6 all are described as binodal infinite networks in terms of Ag and dpma building blocks. As shown in Figure , compounds 1-4 adopt a one-dimensional ladder-like chain structure where Ag and dpma are both considered as three-connected T-nodes; compound 5 has an unusual one-dimensional metallamacrocycle-based chain structure with Ag as two-connected I-node and dpma as three-connected T-node; and compound 6 is a two-dimensional honeycomb-like layer structure with both Ag and dpma as three-connected Y-nodes. The structural diversity and complexity in these Ag-dpma coordination polymers are presumably due to the different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect of the counteranions and solvent molecules. Though NO3 - usually functions as a moderately coordinating monodentate and bidentate anion, here it is not coordinated to the Ag(I) center in compound 1, and is acting as a template toward the formation of a topological ladder Ag-dpma coordination chain. Lacking coordination of the NO3 - anion to the Ag(I) leaves more room around the metal center, allowing the aqua ligand to coordinate to the Ag(I) ion. When a more strongly coordinating CF3CO2 - anion is used, the anions coordinate to Ag(I) ions through one of the oxygen atoms and serve as terminal ligands in compound 2. Changing to the other counteranions such as CF3SO3 - and BF4 - in compounds 3 and 4, respectively, has resulted in the formation of similar one-dimensional ladder structures, in which the CF3SO3 - and BF4 - are significantly involved in the coordination sphere of the Ag(I) center with weak Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅anion contacts. Incorporating weakly coordinating ClO4 - has afforded a completely different metallamacrocycle-based chain structure in 5. Significant Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅O4Cl and Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅OH2 weak coordination interactions are observed, leading to the seesaw and T-shaped Ag(I) coordination geometries. In the two-dimensional honeycomb-layer structure of 6, the noncoordinating PF6 - anions not only act as the counteranions to balance the charge but have a spatial templating effect in building up the coordination network. Moreover, these anions in compounds 1-6 all display noticeable hydrogen-bonding interactions with the amine hydrogens of the dpma ligands and coordinated/lattice water molecules probably act as templates for the formation of the network and consequently maintain the structural stability. However, a straightforward relationship between a given anion and the selective formation of a certain type of supramolecular structures is not yet well understood.

elements.content: The ligand dpma is an attractive flexible N-donor ligand having a three-atomic backbone with hydrogen bonding capabilities. The coordination of dpma ligand possessing two pyridyl and one amine nitrogen atoms to metal ion may give multiple coordination geometries since dpma exhibits inherent conformational flexibility. The conformation of dpma ligand is seen to be quite sensitive to counteranion effects due to the strong hydrogen-bonding propensity of the amine group. Herein, the structures of Ag–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 provide an opportunity to investigate the ligand conformation of dpma in the solid state. In all the six Ag(I) compounds, dpma presents a μ3-bridging mode with various conformations to bind three Ag atoms. As surveyed in Table , these ligand conformations are seen encompassing gauche–trans–anti (1, 2), trans–trans–anti (3, 4), trans–trans–syn (3), gauche–gauche–syn (5), and trans–gauche–syn (6) conformations. The torsion angles around Cpy–C–Nam–C and the dihedral angle about two 3-pyridinyl rings of each ligand is in a wide range of 69.7–180.0° and 16.5–79.4°, respectively, and the Npy-to-Npy distance is in a range of 6.56–8.50 Å. By comparison, dpma ligand in Cu(II)-complex [Cu(μ-dpma)2(μ-1,1-N3)(μ-1,3-N3)] suits a μ2-bridging mode with a trans–gauche–anti conformation, whereas its protonated ammonium form Hdpma+ displays trans–trans–syn and trans–trans–anti conformations in [(NO3 –)⊂{Cu2(μ-Hdpma)4}(NO3)2](NO3)5 and [Cu(μ-Hdpma)2(NCS)2](NO3)2, respectively.

In all the six Ag(I) compounds, dpma presents a μ3-bridging mode with various conformations to bind three Ag atoms. As surveyed in Table , these ligand conformations are seen encompassing gauche-trans-anti (1, 2), trans-trans-anti (3, 4), trans-trans-syn (3), gauche-gauche-syn (5), and trans-gauche-syn (6) conformations. The torsion angles around Cpy-C-Nam-C and the dihedral angle about two 3-pyridinyl rings of each ligand is in a wide range of 69.7-180.0° and 16.5-79.4°, respectively, and the Npy-to-Npy distance is in a range of 6.56-8.50 Å. elements.content: Of particular interest, it is noted that the varied ligand conformations of dpma may offer a profound effect upon the structural modulation of the topologically binodal ladder-like chain structures of 1–4. Even having identical topological conformers, for example, the gauche–trans–anti conformers in 1 and 2 and the trans–trans–anti conformers in 3 and 4, the dpma ligand exhibits fairly different ligating orientations among the three N donors, resulting from the different torsion angles and dihedral angles as well as relative positions of the two ended 3-pyridine N donors. Therefore, a little change on the molecular structure of dpma may cause a drastic twist of the actual ligand conformation, with reversing the relative positions of amine hydrogen and silver atom about the amine nitrogen upon coordination. This is, as illustrated in Figure , directly reflected on the resultant networks of 1–4 in that the orientations of the amine hydrogens direct at three ways of arrangement of a so-called uuuu manner in 1, an uudd manner in 2, and an udud manner in 3 and 4. However, the structural construction of such kinds of polymers is not only influenced by the nature of different counteranions, but they also participate in other types of factors, notably with other ligating species and the solvent systems.

In order to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, the thermal behaviors of silver–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 were studied by thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. The experiments were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S13, ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

In order to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, the thermal behaviors of silver-dpma coordination polymers 1-6 were studied by thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. The experiments were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S13, ).

elements.content: The TG curve of 1 reveals that the coordinated aqua ligands are released between 85–124 °C (found 3.6%, calcd. 4.6%), and the solvent-free coordinative-motif begins to decompose when the temperature is raised to approaching 210 °C. The TG trace for 2 shows that the lattice water molecules are lost between 86–118 °C (found 2.0%, calcd. 2.1%), and the coordinative-framework is retained up to approximately 180 °C, followed by an abrupt decomposition of the framework. For 3, the TG curve exhibits a significant weight loss between 86–101 °C, corresponding to the release of lattice water molecules (found 1.9%, calcd. 1.9%). This is followed by a largely unchanged state until the framework starts to decompose on approaching a temperature of 235 °C. For 4, the TG trace exhibits a gradual weight loss between room temperature and 140 °C, corresponding to the departure of lattice water molecules (found 3.8%, calcd. 4.6% for [Ag(dpma)](BF4)·H2O). Above 140 °C, the guest-free compound shows no weight loss until it reaches ca. 235 °C, and then an abrupt weight loss occurs, indicating the decomposition of the framework. The TG trace for 5 shows that the lattice water molecules are gradually removed in proceeding from room temperature to 140 °C (found 1.4%, calcd. 1.7%), and the framework is retained until it begins to decompose at temperature approaching 250 °C. The TG curve of 6 shows no significant weight loss until the temperature reaches ca. 200 °C, followed by an abrupt decomposition of the species. These data indicate that silver–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 do not show very high thermal stability.

elements.content: There is currently great interest in luminescent compounds because of their potential applications in chemical sensors and photochemistry. Taking the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes into account, the luminescent properties of dpma and Ag–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 were investigated. When irradiated with UV light (λex = 270 nm) at room temperature, the free ligand dpma displays a negligible emission band with λmax at ∼434 nm in acetonitrile solution (Figure , inset). No difference in emission colors has been observed between the free ligand and compounds 1–6 in acetonitrile, which exhibits one emission maxima at ∼431 nm upon photoexcitation at 270 nm (). This probably implies that the polymeric structures disaggregate in acetonitrile solution, as observed in other Ag-based supramolecular materials. In the solid state, compounds 1–6 display one intense fluorescent emission band at 409 ± 2 nm upon 240 nm excitation at room temperature (Figure ), which exhibits a large shift and fluorescence intensity enhancement. Therefore, the emission properties of the free ligand dpma are significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag-containing compounds 1–6. This is, however, somewhat interesting since Ag(I) complexes are generally known to emit weak photoluminescence at low temperature. As a result, compounds 1–6 reported herein represent the unusual examples of room-temperature luminescent Ag-based entities.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

There is currently great interest in luminescent compounds because of their potential applications in chemical sensors and photochemistry. Taking the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes into account, the luminescent properties of dpma and Ag-dpma coordination polymers 1-6 were investigated. When irradiated with UV light (λex = 270 nm) at room temperature, the free ligand dpma displays a negligible emission band with λmax at ~434 nm in acetonitrile solution (Figure , inset). No difference in emission colors has been observed between the free ligand and compounds 1-6 in acetonitrile, which exhibits one emission maxima at ~431 nm upon photoexcitation at 270 nm (). This probably implies that the polymeric structures disaggregate in acetonitrile solution, as observed in other Ag-based supramolecular materials. In the solid state, compounds 1-6 display one intense fluorescent emission band at 409 ± 2 nm upon 240 nm excitation at room temperature (Figure ), which exhibits a large shift and fluorescence intensity enhancement. Therefore, the emission properties of the free ligand dpma are significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag-containing compounds 1-6. This is, however, somewhat interesting since Ag(I) complexes are generally known to emit weak photoluminescence at low temperature. As a result, compounds 1-6 reported herein represent the unusual examples of room-temperature luminescent Ag-based entities.

elements.content: Photoluminescence spectra of silver–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 in the solid state at room temperature (λex = 240 nm). Inset: Photoluminescence spectra of the free ligand dpma in acetonitrile solution at room temperature (λex = 270 nm).

elements.content: Ag–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 are insoluble in common organic solvents. They are slightly soluble in acetonitrile and DMSO, which appear to break down the polymeric structure and result in the formation of discrete molecular species, based on the similar 1H NMR, absorption, and emission spectra of 1–6 and the free ligand in solution ( and ). The 1H NMR spectra of 1–6 in DMSO-d 6 reveal a simple pattern containing one set of four aromatic and one aliphatic sharp resonances, suggesting the formation of one single solution species or the presence of a rapid chemical exchange equilibrium between potential coordination motifs established on the NMR time scale. The latter is certainly possible because labile Ag(I) ions are involved in the coordination process. This lability makes it more challenging to reach conclusions based solely on the NMR study. However, it may be very helpful for the structure characterization of solution assembles when coupled with electrospray mass spectroscopy. The electrospray mass spectra of 1–5 in DMSO/CH3OH solution are analogous and display a main peak corresponding to the [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ (X– = anion) together with two slightly weaker peaks corresponding to [Ag(dpma)2]+ and [Ag(dpma)(DMSO)]+, respectively, consistent with a solution species [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ (). In addition, some weak peaks relating to higher aggregates [Ag3(dpma)3X2]+ (X– = anion) for 1 and 3–5 and [Ag6(dpma)6­(CF3CO2)4]2+ for 2 as well as some intense peaks corresponding to solvated species [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2) and [Ag(DMSO)2]+ are also observed. These findings imply that a dynamic equilibrium exists that involves a series of solution species, and it seems most likely that the predominant species in solution is the [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ ion for 1–5. In the case of 6, peaks corresponding to [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2) are the only observed fragments in the electrospray mass spectra (); no peak related to [Ag n (dpma) m X n–1]+ ion can be assigned. This significantly indicates that the polymeric structure of 6 completely broke down in solution, and then led to the formation of solvated species [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2), as supported by the 1H NMR spectrum that the proton signals, especially the methylene (−CH2−) and the amine (−NH-) hydrogens, are downfield shifted when compared with the spectrum of the free ligand. In other words, the dpma ligands completely dissociate from the coordination sphere of Ag(I) in solution. Interestingly, it is observed that anion effects in solution may also play a role in guiding the formation of solution species. Strong (CF3CO2 –) and weakly (NO3 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and ClO4 –) coordinating anions would lead to the formation of dinuclear species together with tri- or hexanuclear species, respectively, while the noncoordinating (PF6 –) anion would cause complete decomplexation of Ag–dpma complex.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Studies

Ag-dpma coordination polymers 1-6 are insoluble in common organic solvents. They are slightly soluble in acetonitrile and DMSO, which appear to break down the polymeric structure and result in the formation of discrete molecular species, based on the similar 1H NMR, absorption, and emission spectra of 1-6 and the free ligand in solution ( and ). The 1H NMR spectra of 1-6 in DMSO-d 6 reveal a simple pattern containing one set of four aromatic and one aliphatic sharp resonances, suggesting the formation of one single solution species or the presence of a rapid chemical exchange equilibrium between potential coordination motifs established on the NMR time scale. The latter is certainly possible because labile Ag(I) ions are involved in the coordination process. This lability makes it more challenging to reach conclusions based solely on the NMR study. However, it may be very helpful for the structure characterization of solution assembles when coupled with electrospray mass spectroscopy. The electrospray mass spectra of 1-5 in DMSO/CH3OH solution are analogous and display a main peak corresponding to the [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ (X- = anion) together with two slightly weaker peaks corresponding to [Ag(dpma)2]+ and [Ag(dpma)(DMSO)]+, respectively, consistent with a solution species [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ (). In addition, some weak peaks relating to higher aggregates [Ag3(dpma)3X2]+ (X- = anion) for 1 and 3-5 and [Ag6(dpma)6(CF3CO2)4]2+ for 2 as well as some intense peaks corresponding to solvated species [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2) and [Ag(DMSO)2]+ are also observed. These findings imply that a dynamic equilibrium exists that involves a series of solution species, and it seems most likely that the predominant species in solution is the [Ag2(dpma)2X]+ ion for 1-5. In the case of 6, peaks corresponding to [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2) are the only observed fragments in the electrospray mass spectra (); no peak related to [Ag n (dpma) m X n-1]+ ion can be assigned. This significantly indicates that the polymeric structure of 6 completely broke down in solution, and then led to the formation of solvated species [(Hdpma)(DMSO) n ]+ (n = 1, 2), as supported by the 1H NMR spectrum that the proton signals, especially the methylene (-CH2-) and the amine (-NH-) hydrogens, are downfield shifted when compared with the spectrum of the free ligand. In other words, the dpma ligands completely dissociate from the coordination sphere of Ag(I) in solution. Interestingly, it is observed that anion effects in solution may also play a role in guiding the formation of solution species. Strong (CF3CO2 -) and weakly (NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, BF4 -, and ClO4 -) coordinating anions would lead to the formation of dinuclear species together with tri- or hexanuclear species, respectively, while the noncoordinating (PF6 -) anion would cause complete decomplexation of Ag-dpma complex.

elements.content: In this work, the self-assembly reactions of Ag(I) with NO3 –, CF3CO2 –, CF3SO3 –, and BF4 – anions and dpma afforded Ag–dpma coordination polymers 1–4 with one-dimensional binodal ladder-chain structures, whereas similar reactions of Ag(I) with ClO4 – and PF6 – anions and dpma gave Ag–dpma coordination polymers 5 and 6 with a one-dimensional binodal metallamacrocycle-based chain and two-dimensional binodal honeycomb layer, respectively. The roles of the counteranions with different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect in determining the structures of the coordination polymers have been addressed. In terms of anion trends it is reasonably that there is a propensity for coordinating and weakly coordinating anions to give lower dimensional structures, while for noncoordinating anions to yield higher dimensional networks. In addition, for the Ag(I)-dpma system in this work, dpma adopts a μ3-coordination mode with versatile ligand conformations that do depend on the counteranion, leading to the fine-tuning of the polymeric structures. It is also worthy to note that the effects are not restricted to the solid state. In DMSO or acetonitrile solution, the polymeric structures of 1–6 would break down to give multiple rapidly exchanging solution species, and anion effects may also play a role in guiding the formation of solution species.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, the self-assembly reactions of Ag(I) with NO3 -, CF3CO2 -, CF3SO3 -, and BF4 - anions and dpma afforded Ag-dpma coordination polymers 1-4 with one-dimensional binodal ladder-chain structures, whereas similar reactions of Ag(I) with ClO4 - and PF6 - anions and dpma gave Ag-dpma coordination polymers 5 and 6 with a one-dimensional binodal metallamacrocycle-based chain and two-dimensional binodal honeycomb layer, respectively. The roles of the counteranions with different coordinating nature, hydrogen-bonding propensity, and templating effect in determining the structures of the coordination polymers have been addressed. In terms of anion trends it is reasonably that there is a propensity for coordinating and weakly coordinating anions to give lower dimensional structures, while for noncoordinating anions to yield higher dimensional networks. In addition, for the Ag(I)-dpma system in this work, dpma adopts a μ3-coordination mode with versatile ligand conformations that do depend on the counteranion, leading to the fine-tuning of the polymeric structures. It is also worthy to note that the effects are not restricted to the solid state. In DMSO or acetonitrile solution, the polymeric structures of 1-6 would break down to give multiple rapidly exchanging solution species, and anion effects may also play a role in guiding the formation of solution species.

A solution of dpma (39.8 mg, 0.20 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was carefully layered on top of a mixture of MeOH and H2O (6 mL, 1:1 v/v, middle) and a solution of AgNO3 (33.9 mg, 0.20 mmol) in H2O (5 mL, bottom) at room temperature. The solution was allowed to stand for approximately two weeks, resulting in the formation of colorless granule-shaped crystals. Yield 29% (22.1 mg, 0.057 mmol). Alternatively, 1 was also prepared using a procedure similar to that mentioned above except that THF was used in the solvent system instead of MeOH. Yield 42%. Anal. Calcd for C12H15AgN4O4: C, 37.23; H, 3.91; N, 14.47%. Found: C, 37.59; H, 4.12; N, 14.90%. IR (KBr pellet): 3753, 3040, 2851, 2692, 1761, 1596, 1578, 1478, 1458, 1429, 1232, 1189, 1046, 1030, 985, 932, 870, 824, 796, 706, 646 cm–1.

The solution was allowed to stand for approximately two weeks, resulting in the formation of colorless crystals. Yield 28% (24.0 mg, 0.056 mmol). Anal. Calcd for C14H14AgF3N3O2.5: C, 39.18; H, 3.29; N, 9.79%. Found: C, 38.82; H, 3.28; N, 9.56%. A solution of dpma (39.8 mg, 0.20 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was carefully layered on top of a mixture of MeOH and H2O (6 mL, 1:1 v/v, middle) and a solution of AgCF3SO3 (51.3 mg, 0.20 mmol) in H2O (5 mL, bottom) at room temperature. Calcd for C12H16AgBF4N3O1.5: C, 34.24; H, 3.83; N, 9.98%. Found: C, 34.01; H, 3.70; N, 9.85%. A solution of dpma (39.8 mg, 0.20 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was carefully layered on top of a mixture of MeOH and H2O (6 mL, 1:1 v/v, middle) and a solution of AgClO4 (45.6 mg, 0.20 mmol) in H2O (5 mL, bottom) at room temperature. cln_elements.content:
The TG curve of 1 reveals that the coordinated aqua ligands are released between 85–124 °C (found 3.6%, calcd. 4.6%), and the solvent-free coordinative-motif begins to decompose when the temperature is raised to approaching 210 °C. The TG trace for 2 shows that the lattice water molecules are lost between 86–118 °C (found 2.0%, calcd. 2.1%), and the coordinative-framework is retained up to approximately 180 °C, followed by an abrupt decomposition of the framework. For 3, the TG curve exhibits a significant weight loss between 86–101 °C, corresponding to the release of lattice water molecules (found 1.9%, calcd. 1.9%). This is followed by a largely unchanged state until the framework starts to decompose on approaching a temperature of 235 °C. For 4, the TG trace exhibits a gradual weight loss between room temperature and 140 °C, corresponding to the departure of lattice water molecules (found 3.8%, calcd. 4.6% for [Ag(dpma)](BF4)·H2O). Above 140 °C, the guest-free compound shows no weight loss until it reaches ca. 235 °C, and then an abrupt weight loss occurs, indicating the decomposition of the framework. The TG trace for 5 shows that the lattice water molecules are gradually removed in proceeding from room temperature to 140 °C (found 1.4%, calcd. 1.7%), and the framework is retained until it begins to decompose at temperature approaching 250 °C. The TG curve of 6 shows no significant weight loss until the temperature reaches ca. 200 °C, followed by an abrupt decomposition of the species. These data indicate that silver–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 do not show very high thermal stability.

Luminescence Properties

There is currently great interest in luminescent compounds because of their potential applications in chemical sensors and photochemistry. Taking the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes into account, the luminescent properties of dpma and Ag–dpma coordination polymers 1–6 were investigated. When irradiated with UV light (λex = 270 nm) at room temperature, the free ligand dpma displays a negligible emission band with λmax at ∼434 nm in acetonitrile solution (Figure , inset). No difference in emission colors has been observed between the free ligand and compounds 1–6 in acetonitrile, which exhibits one emission maxima at ∼431 nm upon photoexcitation at 270 nm (). This probably implies that the polymeric structures disaggregate in acetonitrile solution, as observed in other Ag-based supramolecular materials. In the solid state, compounds 1–6 display one intense fluorescent emission band at 409 ± 2 nm upon 240 nm excitation at room temperature (Figure ), which exhibits a large shift and fluorescence intensity enhancement. Therefore, the emission properties of the free ligand dpma are significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag-containing compounds 1–6. This is, however, somewhat interesting since Ag(I) complexes are generally known to emit weak photoluminescence at low temperature. As a result, compounds 1–6 reported herein represent the unusual examples of room-temperature luminescent Ag-based entities.
